table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the sound, and not to any letter or glyph.

table.name: mem
table.column: This was used in the plural ({tlhagh patat 'oQqar naQHommey:n:nolink}) to translate "fries" (as in "French fries").

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a type of plant which grows on {Qo'noS:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is an apparatus that creates some sort of force field that counters gravity when descending. The old-fashioned contraption that resembles an umbrella is informally called an {'alwI':n}.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: The object is dirt or soil or a field or a road, not a hole, for which see {ghaw:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: When used with the suffix {-qa':v}, the result has the sense of "retrieve".

▶ {jagh Duj DaQaw' 'ach pagh qama' Datlhapqa'.:sen:nolink} "Destroy enemy vessel without retrieving prisoners."[2] ▶ {qeylIS 'etlh Datlhapqa' 'e' DaQapbe'.:sen:nolink} "Fail to retrieve the Sword of Kahless."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: The song "Monster Mash" was released on Garpax Records. (Note that this is {tlhapragh:n:nolink} written backwards in "xifan hol".)
[1] {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2017:src}, [2] {DSC - The Butcher's Knife Cares Not for the Lamb's Cry:src}

table.name: mem
table.column: In {TNK:src}, this word was used for "clock".

table.name: mem
table.column: Claritin is a brand of allergy medicine.

table.name: mem
table.column: This means to go somewhere and look around. It can also be translated as "scout" or "survey".
It was clarified during the Q & A session that this doesn't take an object, so {loghDaq jItlhargh:sen:nolink} is correct, but not {logh vItlhargh:sen:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This may have been named for the explorer William Clark (of the Lewis and Clark Expedition fame).

table.name: mem
table.column: Clarence Williams III played the character Linc Hayes on the cop show "The Mod Squad".

table.name: mem
table.column: In ascending order of ferocity, the verbs used to describe military confrontations are: {Qor:v}, {tlhaS:v:nolink}, {vay:v}, {lul:v}, {Hargh:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word can be used for the grid on a spreadsheet and also for the gridlines on a map.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is food made from brown leaves, best served without sauce. See {'uSu':n}.
The writers of {DS9 - Melora:src} made up the word "gladst", which contains sounds not possible in standard Klingon. This word is Okrand's backfit.

table.name: mem
table.column: A slang expression for punctuation is {ghewmey:n}. {tlhavqop:n:nolink} is inherently plural, but one can say {tlhavqop ngutlh(mey):n@@tlhavqop:n, ngutlh:n, -mey:n} "punctuation mark(s)".[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to infusing a dead body with some sort of fluid to preserve it. Long ago, Klingons used to do this, but now the practice is observed by only a few Houses.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to animals living in a house.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: This actually appeared as {tlh'a':sen:nolink}, but this is a known typo.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: The Eleventh Tome of Klavek is part of the {paq'batlh:n}, and tells the story of the descent of {qeylIS'e' lIjlaHbe'bogh vay':n:name} into {ghe'tor:n} to rescue his brother.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: Generally, {tlheD:v:nolink} implies setting out on a journey, with a goal or destination in mind, while {mej:v} refers simply to leaving one's current location. In both cases, the object is the place you're leaving or departing from.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: The word "with" (in the sense of "accompanied by") is usually translated by a phrase using this verb.[2; 4] The use of this verb is not restricted to the notion of going somewhere with someone.[4]
In the E-K word list of {TKD:src}, this was erroneously tagged as a noun.

▶ {Dargh vItlhutlhDI' mutlhej torgh matlh je.:sen:nolink}; or {Dargh vItlhutlh. mutlhej torgh matlh je.:sen:nolink}; or {Dargh vItlhutlh 'ej mutlhej torgh matlh je.:sen:nolink} "I drink tea with Torg and Maltz."[2] ▶ {bIQongtaHvIS nItlhejchugh targhmey bIvemDI' nItlhej ghIlab ghewmey.:sen}[3] ▶ {QotDI' gheD tlhejbe' wamwI'.:sen}[3] ▶ {'Iw HIq vItlhutlh. mutlhej ghaH.:sen:nolink} "He/she drinks bloodwine with me."[4]

table.name: mem
table.column: Clem Kadiddlehopper was a country bumpkin character portrayed by Red Skelton.

table.name: mem
table.column: sound as, produce the sound of
This is used with sound nouns, such as {bobDar:n}, {lu'lap:n}, {rIS:n}, and {SuqwIl:n}. It can also be used with {QoQ:n} as its object or with no object.[1]
That {QoQ:n:nolink} is a possible object and that there is no problem using this without an object was clarified during the Q & A session.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a type of plant. In the {paq'batlh:src}, it is mentioned that the {ngeng HeH:n} of the {qul ngeng:n} inside {QIStaq:n} has an environment so hostile to life that not even the {tlheng'IQ:n:nolink} would grow there.
According to the novel {Kahless:src}, this plant flowers only every eight years.

table.name: mem
table.column: Klingons would probably describe straight hair as {tlhep:v}, whereas wavy hair is said to {ve'Ha':v}.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This word appears to contain the element {tlhep:v}, though this might just be a coincidence.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a reference to a character named "Clar"ence Rutherford, who is nicknamed "Lumpy", from the television show "Leave It to Beaver". See {warjun:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: type of spear (thrown with aid of a special tool)

table.name: mem
table.column: To say "to smoke" (as in inhale nicotine), use {tlhIch pur:sen@@tlhIch:n, pur:v}.[2] To smoke other kinds of plants, it's also possible to say {por pur:sen}.[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: According to the glossary to {A Burning House:src}, this is a predatory animal with sharp teeth that it bares before attacking.

table.name: mem
table.column: you plural, you all, y'all, yall, yinz

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the extraction of resources (see {jo:n}) such as minerals (see {tlhIl:n}), and not to the deployment of explosives (see {jorwI':n}).

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a place where minerals ({tlhIl:n}) are extracted ({tlhIl:v}), and not to a proximity explosive.

In the {Haynes BoP Manual:src}, this word was incorrectly used to refer to proximity explosives. (It was also misspelled as {tlhHl:sen:nolink}, perhaps deliberately in an attempt to make it look like a different word.)

table.name: mem
table.column:
The verb for laying a carpet is {vel:v}. The verb {mutlh:v}, when applied to a carpet, means to assemble it.
The word {tlhIm:n:nolink} is also used for a fabric wall hanging. A {tlhIm:n:nolink} has to cover something. A fabric displayed at the end of a pole would be a {joqwI':n}.
Finally, {tlhIm:n:nolink} can also be used for a blanket, though Klingons generally don't use blankets.
A "gelim" is a type of Persian carpet.

table.name: mem
table.column: According to {A Good Day to Die:src}, this is made from something orange.

table.name: mem
table.column: This does not mean simply "single, separate" but rather something like "be attributable to something or someone" or "be uniquely associated with something or someone".[1]

This was defined as "be particular, individual", followed by a long explanation. The "one's own" clarification was added based on this clarification.[1]
When asked whether the word {qangtlhIn:n} is related, MO said he did not know of any relationship.[1]
In many languages, the endonym for its speakers means something like "our own people".

▶ {DujwIj tlhIn:n@@Duj:n:1, -wIj:n, tlhIn:v} "my particular ship, my own ship"[1] ▶ {betleHlIj vIneHbe', betleHwIj tlhIn vIghaj:sen@@betleH:n, -lIj:n, vI-:v, neH:v, -be':v, betleH:n, -wIj:n, tlhIn:v, vI-:v, ghaj:v} "I don't want your bat'leth, I have my own bat'leth"[1] ▶ {DujDaj tlhIn legh HoD:sen@@Duj:n:1, -Daj:n, tlhIn:v, legh:v, HoD:n} "The captain sees his/her own ship" (might be ambiguous whether the ship is the captain's or someone else's, depending on context)[1] ▶ {jagh Duj tlhIn legh HoD:sen@@jagh:n, Duj:n:1, tlhIn:v, legh:v, HoD:n} "The captain sees the enemy's own ship"[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: klin zha, a popular board game
This is a game of strategy which has been compared to chess.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {tlhIngan juHqo'Daq tlhIng yoSDaq 'oH toQDuj chenmoHlu'meH Daq wa'DIch'e':sen@@tlhIngan:n, juHqo':n, -Daq:n, tlhIng yoS:n, -Daq:n, 'oH:n, toQDuj:n, chenmoH:v, -lu':v, -meH:v, Daq:n, wa'DIch:n, -'e':n} "1st Construction Site: The Kling District, Klingon Home World"

table.name: mem
table.column:
Note that this refers to a Klingon person or to the Klingon people, but not to the Klingon language (for which see {tlhIngan Hol:n}). In Klingon, unlike in Federation Standard, the name of a language is not simply the name of the people who speak it, but must be an identifier followed by the word {Hol:n}.
There is an idiom, {Hem; tlhIngan rur@@Hem:v, tlhIngan:n, rur:v}.
The TKD entry says only "Klingon". The "(person)" annotation has been added to distinguish this entry from "Klingon (language)", and to make it consistent with the entry for "Vulcan (person)", etc.
▶ {Hem tlhIngan Segh 'ej maHemtaH 'e' wIHech.:sen} ▶ {bogh tlhInganpu', SuvwI'pu' moj, Hegh.:sen}

table.name: mem
table.column: This is short for {tlhIngan wo' Hol:n:nolink}.[3]
This term doesn't actually appear in the word lists in {TKD:src}, but is used in the list of useful expressions.

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: Please visit the KLI website at {www.kli.org:url:http://www.kli.org/} for more information.

table.name: mem
table.column: The official {QI':n} of the Klingon Empire, run by the {ra'ghomquv:n}. It is subdivided into {yo':n} and {nawlogh:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: Klingons kill for their own purposes.

table.name: mem
table.column: When you insult a Klingon's honor, prepare for trouble.
When you insult a Klingon's honour, prepare for trouble.

table.name: mem
table.column: The language spoken in the Klingon Empire is called {tlhIngan wo' Hol:n:nolink}, or {tlhIngan Hol:n} for short.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a private joke referring to a specific person.

table.name: mem
table.column: If you spit out liquid, then {bItuy':sen:nolink}, but if you spit out solids, then {bItlhIS:sen:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a name from {wIlyam SeQpIr:n:name}'s play {'antonI' tlhI'yopatra' je:sen:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This verb is used to make a request, whereas {ghel:v} is used for asking a question.[3]

This was defined as "ask" in {TKD:src}, but as "request, ask, plead" in {TKDA:src}.
The examples show that the object of this verb can be the person of whom the request is made, or {'e':n:pro} referring to the action which is requested. The definition suggests that a thing which is requested might be a possible object, but this isn't clear.

table.name: mem
table.column: be somewhat obscured, filtered, smudged, fuzzy
▶ {wa'Hu' jul tlhoDmoHmo' 'eng} "Because it was (sort of) cloudy yesterday", literally, "Because yesterday clouds somewhat obscured the sun"

table.name: mem
table.column:
This word was long considered quaint or archaic, but is heard with increasing frequency. Unlike {Saw:v} and {nay:v}, it can be used by either partner regardless of sex or gender.
One can say either {B tlhogh A:sen:nolink} for "{A:sen:nolink} marries {B:sen:nolink}" or {tlhoghchuq A B je:sen:nolink} "{A:sen:nolink} and {B:sen:nolink} marry each other".

table.name: mem
table.column: The object of this verb is plural.

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: This refers to the visual phenomenon in the sky, not the technical moment of sunset.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is made by coating a block of {tlhagh:n} with {ngat:n:2} and {tIr:n}, then {mIQ:v}.[1, p.93]

table.name: mem
table.column: According to the glossary to {A Burning House:src}, this is much larger than a {targh:n}, more difficult to subdue, and is sometimes used as a riding beast.

table.name: mem
table.column: For the front section of an object, see {'et:n:2h}. See also {lurgh:n} for other words related to spatial directions.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is just an extension of {tlhop:n:1} in a specific context. The idea is that a public area would be in front of some barrier used to keep the public out, while the private area would be on the other side.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is generally the object of a verb like {tur:v}. The recipient of the favor is marked with {-vaD:n:suff}.

"One good turn deserves another ({latlh qotlh:sen@@latlh:n, qotlh:v:2})".
The request that resulted in this word specified that a favor is "an act done out of goodwill rather than from justice or renumeration", so the word may be narrower in scope than all possible meanings of the English word "favor".

table.name: mem
table.column: almost, nearly, virtually, not quite; barely
When used with a negative verb, this has the meaning of "barely".[2]

"Close".
This was defined as "almost, nearly, virtually, not quite" in {KGT:src}. The "barely" meaning was added at {qep'a' 25 (2018):src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: If a bird lands on a tree, the verb {ngun:v} is used, and if on land, then {Saq:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is missing from the E-K side of {TKD:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: overly, to an excessive degree, excessively, too much

table.name: mem
table.column: wall, interior wall, interior face of exterior wall, territorial wall
Also refers to floors/ceilings, see {tlhoy' SaS:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: In Klingon hotels, there is no tipping because there is no service. The concept of tipping is weird to Klingons, but a tip could be called this.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: Note that while it's possible to say "Thank you" ({qatlho'}) in Klingon, this is something which Klingons would not normally say.

In {TNG - The Mind's Eye:src}, Captain Jean-Luc Picard ({janluq pIqarD:n:name}) said {qatlho':sen:nolink} to Kell after the latter paid him a compliment. Kell responded with an odd look.[2]
At {qep'a' loSDIch:src}, MO explained that he never intended {qatlho':sen:nolink} to mean "thanks" (in the way English speakers use that expression).

table.name: mem
table.column: unit of volume (approx. one quart/liter), klorn

The newsgroup message says only that one {tlho'ren:n:nolink} "seems to be in the quart/liter range."[1]
The spelling of "klorn" comes from the script to {DS9 - Blood Oath:src}.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the height of action in a narrative. (It is not used for orgasm, for which see {'ebraH:n}.)[1]

table.name: mem
table.column:
It is unclear if this means "to tire someone out" (see {Doy':v}), "to use something up completely" (see {natlh:v:1}), or (as in English) both.
Previously, some people believed that this word means "to expel exhaust", based on its similarity to {tlhuH:v:1}, and that {ghImwI':n:nolink} was a mistake for {tlhuchwI':n:nolink}. See the KLI Round Table in {HQ 11.2, p.10, Jun. 2002:src}. However, further information on {ghIm:v} since then have confirmed that {ghImwI':n:nolink} is correct.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {chIch vay' 'oy'moHmeH 'oy'naQ 'ul law' tlhuD 'oH.:sen:nolink} "[Klingon painstiks] emit a highly-charged shock for the express purpose of inflicting pain."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: be exhilarated, be stimulated, be invigorated

table.name: mem
table.column: This is missing from the E-K side of {TKD:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This means to grab in midair, like catching a baseball.

table.name: mem
table.column: The difference between {tlhutmoH:v@@tlhut:v, -moH:v} and {ghoD:v} is that for the latter, the container is used to hold or store what you're putting into it, such as a pinata, whereas {tlhut:v:nolink} is used for filling something to have a certain shape or look, such as with taxidermy and stuffed animals.

table.name: mem
table.column: See under {tlhej:v} and {'e' qa':sen} for more examples.

table.name: mem
table.column: tlhutlhmeH HIq ngeb qaq law' bIQ qaq puS.
Drinking fake ale is better than drinking water.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a person who not only died (or was killed) for a belief or cause, but who has become a symbol or emblem or rallying point of or for that belief or cause.[1]
